Members
President Royster issued the
following statement: "All committees will meet Thursday at
12:20 in Latrobe 120, immediately
after the assembly."
Announcing a new set-up in the
administration of class offairs, John
Royster, president of the Sophomore
Class, has appointed a general comrnittee of three to coordinate and aid
the sub-committees for the Sophomore Banquet and the FreshmanSophomore Dance. The trio named
are Lex Sklenar, chairman; Tom Ellis, and Bernard Vincenti, who will
serve as ex-officio members of the
other two committees.
Those named to the Banquet Committee are James Lyle, chairman;
Robertson Hesse, Royce Russell, Leroy Cooper, Charley Meushaw, Stanley M. Prager, Munroe Suresky, and
Rod Shipley.
Dance Committee
On the Dance Committee are John
Ghingher, chairman; William GoodMan, William L. Snyder, Judge Mehlling, Robert Austrian, William Wagner, and Stanley M. Finkel.
The banquet will be held some day
during the allotted season — from
Wednesday, April 15 to Saturday,
April 18. In all probability, the combined dance will be held on Saturday
night.
In commenting on his announced
plans, Royster stated:
"We have introduced this innovation in the hopes of running the two
affairs more smoothly and efficiently.
The general committee will serve as
a coordinating body to the two subordinate committees. I hope that by
doing this we will keep the activity
Of the committees at a fast pace and
keep the group on their toes.
"Is New Idea"
"This combined dance is a new
idea and we can put it over with a
bang if we work hard and have decent cooperation. The committee is
a representative body and I have
some novel suggestions to make to
them when they meet. We are starting to work immediately and will announce further plans when we meet
With the freshman group."
Besides Royster, the other officers
are Harold Jacobs, vice-president;
treasurer;
Counselman,
Charles
Frank Crist, secretary; and Edward
Clautice, sergeant-at-arms.

Acording to Wrenn, Lewis, and
Jencks, architects for the new faculty club building, bids will be opened
on the 25th of March, and the contract will be awarded approximately
one week from that time. The building has been made possible by a fund
established nearly thirty years ago
by Theodore, Amelia, and the late
William A. Marburg as a memorial
to their late brother, the late Charles
Louis Marburg.
Dr. Isaiah Bowman, president of
the university, stated that at the
time of the gift it was not considered
desirable to erect the building immediately because of existing conditions; and with the consent of the
donors, the income from the grant
has been used for general expenses
of the school until now. The original gift was $50,000, but with the
death of William Marburg, the surviving brother and sister made another bequest of $30,000.
Additional Sum Added
In addition to the $80,000 an additional sum has been provided, which
will be sufficient to pay for heating
and lighting the new club building.
Thus, through the foresight and generosity of the donors, the club will
be operated without any expenditure
of the university's funds.
Commenting on the gift, Dr. Bowman said: "I regard the Marburg
gift as evidence of the faith of the
donors in the present as well as the
future usefulness of the university.
Both faculty and trustees welcome
the gift as a memorial to members of
a family which has been closely associated with the Hopkins for many
years and whose members have always displayed a keen and intelligent
interest in the cultural development
of Baltimore."
Of Georgian Design
The building will be a two-story
structure of Georgian design in harmony with the rest of the buildings
at Homewood. It will be situated on
the north side of the university's
botanical gardens facing the botanical laboratory behind Gilman Hall.
A lounge, dining rooms, card and
cloak rooms, etc. have been provided
for in the central part of the building by the architects. One of the
wings will contain a billiard room
and the other wing will contain a dining room for women connected with
the university. A smoking room,
locker rooms, and showers will occupy the basement.
At the request of the donors, the
building will be considered as a memorial to both Charles, Louis, and William Marburg. Work on the building
will start as soon after the awarding
of the contract as possible.

League Announces
Series Of Concerts Playshop
The Johns Hopkins chapter of the
American League Against War and
Fascism has announced a series of
three chamber music recitals to be
presented on Friday evening, March
20; Friday evening, April 10; and
Thursday evening, May 4, at 8:30
p. m. Samuel Goldster and Leo Krakow, violinists; Jerome Rosenthal,
violist; and Mischa Midelinan, cellist, members of the National Symphony Orchestra, have been engaged
for the recitals.
Subscription to the series are one
dollar each; individual concerts, forty
cents. Tickets may be obtained at
the Frigate Bookshop, 515 N. Howard Street; the International Bookshop, 501 N. Eutaw St.; 522 Park
Ave., room 10; or at Box 1109, Johns
liopkins University.

Call For Track Men
With a heavy schedule facing
them, the Johns Hopkins trackmen
have been working out on the athletic field since Monday. Last week,
Coach Waldo Hambleton issued a call
for new candidates.
"This year's team will need all the
Eiupport it can have," said Hambleton. "We welcome any newcomers."

To Give Extra
Performance Of "Fires"

The Johns Hopkins Playshop has
announced that Sudermann's The
Fires of St. John will be held over
for an extra performance on Friday,
March 6, at the Playshop.
Five performances have already
been given by the cast which includes Elsie Kane, Patty Singewald,
Annette Jurgens, Jane Murray, Dorothy Blumberg, Ray Williams, William S. Hart, Melvin Scheidt and
Cassriel Applestein, under direction
of N. Bryllion Fag,in, associate professor in the English Department.

Dr. Alevander G. Christie, professor of mechanical engineering, last
week announced that an attempt will
be made to inaugurate a series of lectures by prominent scientists, with
the initial talk scheduled for today
at 5 p. m. in Maryland Hall. This
series, Dr. Christie said, will be open
to the public in an effort to "stimulate interest in industry".
"When the Hopkins University
was founded many years ago", Dr.
Christie said, "Professor Huxley and
other prominent scientists
were
brought here to give public lectures
in order to stimulate interest in
scientific developments. We are attempting to follow the same course
in offering this series of technical
lectures to a wide public audience
in Baltimore in the hopes that this
will stimulate interest in industry."
The lecture schedule follows:
Wednesday, March 4th, "Crystalization and the Theory of Alloys".
Professor A. G. Christie.

James T. Shotwell Talks
In Latrobe Tomorrow
Dr. James T. Shotwell, director
of the division of economics and
history at the Carnegie Endowment for International Peace, will
deliver two lectures in Latrobe
Hall at 5 p. m. tomorrow and
Friday.
Dr. Shotwell will speak tomorrow on "‘An Appeal to Reason."
Friday he will discuss "The History and Organization of Peace."
Sponsored by the Meier Katz
Memorial Lectures, the lectures
are directed by the University's
Walter Hines Page School of International Relations.

succeed John Murphy, who resigned
because of a heavy scholastic schedule. Murphy, who was the first junior ever to be named to the committee, has expressed his wishes for the
success of Edelmann and offered his
services in an ex-officio capacity if
desired.
Edelmann is a member of the Phi

basketball team, treasurer of his
class for three years, and served on
the NEWS-LETTER editorial staff for
two years. He has appointed to his

Ten Assistant Treasurers
Ten assistant treasurers have also
been appointed to aid in the collection of the class dues. This committee consists of
Julian Gelber
Harry Goldberg
Herman Castlebrauner
Bernard Maisel
Irving Leberfeld
Edward Hatfield
Isaiah Miller
Tom Callahan
Algonquin Eppes
Harold Kropman.
It will be their duty to contact the
members of the Senior Class to extract their back dues.

New Junior Dues Plan
Announced By President
The president of the Junior Class
Monday announced a new plan of collecting dues. The Junior Class will be
divided into units of 10 men each,
and committees will be appointed so
that there will be one man in charge
of each unit. The duties of this man
will be to get in touch with the fellows to collect the dues and to keep
them informed of class meetings.
There is a possibility of no Junior
Prom being held this year if this
plan does not work.

Military Ball To Be
Held On March 14
The annual Military Ball will take
place Saturday evening, March 14th,
from 9 to 1 at Levering Hall with
the cost of subscription placed at
$1.25.
The committee, comprising Vernon
Kelly, Henry Severn, Bernie Maisel,
Jimmy McGarrity, and Warren Bittrick have announced that they are
working independently of the Cotillion
Board and have reserved the Townsmen for the evening. The hall will be
decorated as usual and the evening
filled with events to be climaxed by
a grand march with crossed sabers.
All cadet officers from Maryland,
Western Maryland, Penn State, and
Rutgers have been invited to attend.
President Bowman, Dean Berry,
Doctors Hubbard, Christie, Cowes;
Colonel Hoisington, Major Coffin and
Lieutenant Reeves will be among the
honored guests at the dance.

A. S. U. TO HEAR HOLT
Dr. W. Stull Holt, associate professor of history at the Hopkins, will
speak to the local branch of the
American Student Union at its
weekly meeting on Friday.
Dr. Holt will talk on the financial
situation of the'University. The meeting will be held in Levering Hall and
will begin at 1 p. m.

The Revival Of An Art
BY EDGAR KEMLER
There are just two kinds of people you run into these days. There
are those who see clearly the enormous suffering in the world and those
who ,blindly prosper by its perpetration.
It is truly astonishing how little these prosperous ones know of the
distasteful truths behind contemporary strikes, wars, and tyrannies. There
is a sort of middle-class genius at building a world in which mass ugliness is safely concealed from view.
So, it has interested me of late to discover what happens to the
reputations of Great Men in the hands of these two groups—so sharply
divided in their outlook at the present time.
Now, I feel quite sure that this is a time of truly Great Men. And
Great Men are as rare as active volcanoes. Here and abroad, there is such
an abundance of volcanic demagogues—the like of which has hardly been
seen since the Renaissance. Yet where is the audience to rejoice in such
fertility?
On one side, my social-injustice friends get quite hysterical at the
mention of Hitler, Mussolini, or Kemal Pasha. And, on the other, it would
seem, my exploitatory friends don't know or care about them. As to that,
a recent Fortune survey statistically revealed large numbers quite indiferent to whatever goes on outside of their immediate-neighbor's beds.
And, from every indication, when they finally find out the truth, they will
go hysterically the other way—to Fascism.
Already, it appears, a clans-war of hysterical sympathies is starting
with the Great Men's reputations being completely warped on both sides.
Few of the reading public today regard such men as Hitler, Mussolini, Stalin, Rev. Coughlin, and Herb Hoover as human beings any more
—complete with mothers, opinions, high blood pressure, kidney trouble,
or bad investments. In short, publicists, who are the most vehement of
men, don't assign to dictators the qualities which distinguish humans
from god-heads, on one hand, and beasts, on the other. Some radical
spokesmen, for example, regard Stalin as a plaster saint and Hitler as
a plaster devil, an impossible beast. And the Hearst press is just about

There is thus none to relish the true colors of a Great Man. In general, we tend to look at our Great very much as the superstitious peas-

I

STRIKE

ants of the Middle Ages used to regard dragons, ogres, and elves. It was
impossible for one of those peasants to conceive that an ogre might have

BRAND

B

bladder trouble, just as much as he had.
Thus I decided to write a series of short plays—returning our Great
Men to the human fold (and when I say "human", I don't necessarily

BRAND

C

BRAND

D

I

mean that always as a compliment).
But to humanize a Hitler demands an apology. For so far has the
current hysteria advanced that I must go at length to argue that there
is really some reason for doing it. In brief, my reason is that the contemplation of remarkable human beings in their array of true colors is
one of the great joys of life. In the midst of all the madness of murders
and glory, all of us can take a little time out and bring down the cutthroats from their horses with an Aristophanic roar. That is the end
of living. That roar of the intellect gives you faith in the riches of life,
whatever your station—and what else can now do a like service? It's
ray of sunshine in an otherwise capitalistic world!
Now to unhorse a tyrant, you need little trite incidents. What would
happen, I ask, if the common situations which are customary in theatrical plots happen to the world's mighty, just as to other matinee idols?
But here's the problem. It is next to impossible to discover such
mortal incidents in the real life of our present dictators. They're all wellhidden. As all our tyrants have risen democratically and unheralded,
there was no biographer to catch them in their obscurity—as was the
case in the absurd, but recorded rise of the third Napoleon. Such mortal
youths are known only to the tyrants themselves, for obviously it's bad
business to expose such facts and thus establish blood kinship to one's
very humblest subject.
Now I don't really know what bits of scarlet color, Hoover, Hitler,
and Stalin have. Therefore, I am inventing bits for them. And that, as
you know, amounts to libel!
But a libel is unethical, you say. And from one point of view, I suppose it is. But let us remember the loftiness of our aim. We are libeling
as the only method of making human our fellow creatures of Earth.
The Greeks—Aristophanes--used it. Why can't we in the good old U. S.
A.? There's plenty of immorality in American business tactics. So,
why can't there be just a little in American letters? To the officials who
have already banned an Elmer Rice portrayal of the Great Men of the
world, I say, gentlemen, let's play the game. Writers will stop picking
on crooked Babbitts, if the latter stop on crooked literati.
I have now almost completed three plays in the technique above discussed. The portraits are as lifelike as the facts permit. Whether I have
been successful remains to be seen. But I am convinced that the libel is
—and rightly so—a brilliant literary tool. What with Walter Winchell
et al, it really should need no introduction in the United States. What it
needs is universal application to the bogies that are now causing so
so much hysteria.
(A libelous Hitler play will appear in a forthcoming issue.)

JOINT DANCE IS PLAN

Sklenar Is Chairman; Ellis
And Vincenti Are Other
Members
President Royster issued the
following statement: "All committees will meet Thursday at
12:20 in Latrobe 120, immediately
after the assembly."
Announcing a new set-up in the
administration of class offairs, John
Royster, president of the Sophomore
Class, has appointed a general comrnittee of three to coordinate and aid
the sub-committees for the Sophomore Banquet and the FreshmanSophomore Dance. The trio named
are Lex Sklenar, chairman; Tom Ellis, and Bernard Vincenti, who will
serve as ex-officio members of the
other two committees.
Those named to the Banquet Committee are James Lyle, chairman;
Robertson Hesse, Royce Russell, Leroy Cooper, Charley Meushaw, Stanley M. Prager, Munroe Suresky, and
Rod Shipley.
Dance Committee
On the Dance Committee are John
Ghingher, chairman; William GoodMan, William L. Snyder, Judge Mehlling, Robert Austrian, William Wagner, and Stanley M. Finkel.
The banquet will be held some day
during the allotted season — from
Wednesday, April 15 to Saturday,
April 18. In all probability, the combined dance will be held on Saturday
night.
In commenting on his announced
plans, Royster stated:
"We have introduced this innovation in the hopes of running the two
affairs more smoothly and efficiently.
The general committee will serve as
a coordinating body to the two subordinate committees. I hope that by
doing this we will keep the activity
Of the committees at a fast pace and
keep the group on their toes.
"Is New Idea"
"This combined dance is a new
idea and we can put it over with a
bang if we work hard and have decent cooperation. The committee is
a representative body and I have
some novel suggestions to make to
them when they meet. We are starting to work immediately and will announce further plans when we meet
With the freshman group."
Besides Royster, the other officers
are Harold Jacobs, vice-president;
treasurer;
Counselman,
Charles
Frank Crist, secretary; and Edward
Clautice, sergeant-at-arms.

Acording to Wrenn, Lewis, and
Jencks, architects for the new faculty club building, bids will be opened
on the 25th of March, and the contract will be awarded approximately
one week from that time. The building has been made possible by a fund
established nearly thirty years ago
by Theodore, Amelia, and the late
William A. Marburg as a memorial
to their late brother, the late Charles
Louis Marburg.
Dr. Isaiah Bowman, president of
the university, stated that at the
time of the gift it was not considered
desirable to erect the building immediately because of existing conditions; and with the consent of the
donors, the income from the grant
has been used for general expenses
of the school until now. The original gift was $50,000, but with the
death of William Marburg, the surviving brother and sister made another bequest of $30,000.
Additional Sum Added
In addition to the $80,000 an additional sum has been provided, which
will be sufficient to pay for heating
and lighting the new club building.
Thus, through the foresight and generosity of the donors, the club will
be operated without any expenditure
of the university's funds.
Commenting on the gift, Dr. Bowman said: "I regard the Marburg
gift as evidence of the faith of the
donors in the present as well as the
future usefulness of the university.
Both faculty and trustees welcome
the gift as a memorial to members of
a family which has been closely associated with the Hopkins for many
years and whose members have always displayed a keen and intelligent
interest in the cultural development
of Baltimore."
Of Georgian Design
The building will be a two-story
structure of Georgian design in harmony with the rest of the buildings
at Homewood. It will be situated on
the north side of the university's
botanical gardens facing the botanical laboratory behind Gilman Hall.
A lounge, dining rooms, card and
cloak rooms, etc. have been provided
for in the central part of the building by the architects. One of the
wings will contain a billiard room
and the other wing will contain a dining room for women connected with
the university. A smoking room,
locker rooms, and showers will occupy the basement.
At the request of the donors, the
building will be considered as a memorial to both Charles, Louis, and William Marburg. Work on the building
will start as soon after the awarding
of the contract as possible.

League Announces
Series Of Concerts Playshop
The Johns Hopkins chapter of the
American League Against War and
Fascism has announced a series of
three chamber music recitals to be
presented on Friday evening, March
20; Friday evening, April 10; and
Thursday evening, May 4, at 8:30
p. m. Samuel Goldster and Leo Krakow, violinists; Jerome Rosenthal,
violist; and Mischa Midelinan, cellist, members of the National Symphony Orchestra, have been engaged
for the recitals.
Subscription to the series are one
dollar each; individual concerts, forty
cents. Tickets may be obtained at
the Frigate Bookshop, 515 N. Howard Street; the International Bookshop, 501 N. Eutaw St.; 522 Park
Ave., room 10; or at Box 1109, Johns
liopkins University.

Call For Track Men
With a heavy schedule facing
them, the Johns Hopkins trackmen
have been working out on the athletic field since Monday. Last week,
Coach Waldo Hambleton issued a call
for new candidates.
"This year's team will need all the
Eiupport it can have," said Hambleton. "We welcome any newcomers."

To Give Extra
Performance Of "Fires"

The Johns Hopkins Playshop has
announced that Sudermann's The
Fires of St. John will be held over
for an extra performance on Friday,
March 6, at the Playshop.
Five performances have already
been given by the cast which includes Elsie Kane, Patty Singewald,
Annette Jurgens, Jane Murray, Dorothy Blumberg, Ray Williams, William S. Hart, Melvin Scheidt and
Cassriel Applestein, under direction
of N. Bryllion Fag,in, associate professor in the English Department.

Dr. Alevander G. Christie, professor of mechanical engineering, last
week announced that an attempt will
be made to inaugurate a series of lectures by prominent scientists, with
the initial talk scheduled for today
at 5 p. m. in Maryland Hall. This
series, Dr. Christie said, will be open
to the public in an effort to "stimulate interest in industry".
"When the Hopkins University
was founded many years ago", Dr.
Christie said, "Professor Huxley and
other prominent scientists
were
brought here to give public lectures
in order to stimulate interest in
scientific developments. We are attempting to follow the same course
in offering this series of technical
lectures to a wide public audience
in Baltimore in the hopes that this
will stimulate interest in industry."
The lecture schedule follows:
Wednesday, March 4th, "Crystalization and the Theory of Alloys".
Professor A. G. Christie.

James T. Shotwell Talks
In Latrobe Tomorrow
Dr. James T. Shotwell, director
of the division of economics and
history at the Carnegie Endowment for International Peace, will
deliver two lectures in Latrobe
Hall at 5 p. m. tomorrow and
Friday.
Dr. Shotwell will speak tomorrow on "‘An Appeal to Reason."
Friday he will discuss "The History and Organization of Peace."
Sponsored by the Meier Katz
Memorial Lectures, the lectures
are directed by the University's
Walter Hines Page School of International Relations.

Ten Assistant Treasurers
Ten assistant treasurers have also
been appointed to aid in the collection of the class dues. This committee consists of
Julian Gelber
Harry Goldberg
Herman Castlebrauner
Bernard Maisel
Irving Leberfeld
Edward Hatfield
Isaiah Miller
Tom Callahan
Algonquin Eppes
Harold Kropman.
It will be their duty to contact the
members of the Senior Class to extract their back dues.

New Junior Dues Plan
Announced By President
The president of the Junior Class
Monday announced a new plan of collecting dues. The Junior Class will be
divided into units of 10 men each,
and committees will be appointed so
that there will be one man in charge
of each unit. The duties of this man
will be to get in touch with the fellows to collect the dues and to keep
them informed of class meetings.
There is a possibility of no Junior
Prom being held this year if this
plan does not work.

Military Ball To Be
Held On March 14
The annual Military Ball will take
place Saturday evening, March 14th,
from 9 to 1 at Levering Hall with
the cost of subscription placed at
$1.25.
The committee, comprising Vernon
Kelly, Henry Severn, Bernie Maisel,
Jimmy McGarrity, and Warren Bittrick have announced that they are
working independently of the Cotillion
Board and have reserved the Townsmen for the evening. The hall will be
decorated as usual and the evening
filled with events to be climaxed by
a grand march with crossed sabers.
All cadet officers from Maryland,
Western Maryland, Penn State, and
Rutgers have been invited to attend.
President Bowman, Dean Berry,
Doctors Hubbard, Christie, Cowes;
Colonel Hoisington, Major Coffin and
Lieutenant Reeves will be among the
honored guests at the dance.

A. S. U. TO HEAR HOLT
Dr. W. Stull Holt, associate professor of history at the Hopkins, will
speak to the local branch of the
American Student Union at its
weekly meeting on Friday.
Dr. Holt will talk on the financial
situation of the'University. The meeting will be held in Levering Hall and
will begin at 1 p. m.

WHY LIB

The Revival Of An Art
BY EDGAR KEMLER
There are just two kinds of people you run into these days. There
are those who see clearly the enormous suffering in the world and those
who ,blindly prosper by its perpetration.
It is truly astonishing how little these prosperous ones know of the
distasteful truths behind contemporary strikes, wars, and tyrannies. There
is a sort of middle-class genius at building a world in which mass ugliness is safely concealed from view.
So, it has interested me of late to discover what happens to the
reputations of Great Men in the hands of these two groups—so sharply
divided in their outlook at the present time.
Now, I feel quite sure that this is a time of truly Great Men. And
Great Men are as rare as active volcanoes. Here and abroad, there is such
an abundance of volcanic demagogues—the like of which has hardly been
seen since the Renaissance. Yet where is the audience to rejoice in such
fertility?
On one side, my social-injustice friends get quite hysterical at the
mention of Hitler, Mussolini, or Kemal Pasha. And, on the other, it would
seem, my exploitatory friends don't know or care about them. As to that,
a recent Fortune survey statistically revealed large numbers quite indiferent to whatever goes on outside of their immediate-neighbor's beds.
And, from every indication, when they finally find out the truth, they will
go hysterically the other way—to Fascism.
Already, it appears, a clans-war of hysterical sympathies is starting
with the Great Men's reputations being completely warped on both sides.
Few of the reading public today regard such men as Hitler, Mussolini, Stalin, Rev. Coughlin, and Herb Hoover as human beings any more
—complete with mothers, opinions, high blood pressure, kidney trouble,
or bad investments. In short, publicists, who are the most vehement of
men, don't assign to dictators the qualities which distinguish humans
from god-heads, on one hand, and beasts, on the other. Some radical
spokesmen, for example, regard Stalin as a plaster saint and Hitler as
a plaster devil, an impossible beast. And the Hearst press is just about

The cooling breeze, incense laden,
fragrant
With honeysuckle's pungent breath;
The whispered monologue of trees—
They held no charms for one of these:
Shadows and shells of men—vagrant.
Now brown, now green, as wave on
wave the wheat
Rolled surging in the wind and
broke
In little rustling on the lea,
Some flotsam leaves whirled on this
sea—
Flotsam (wreckage of the streets)
Trudged by like the derelict leaves
on fields of grain,
Driven by the winds of hunger;
Plodding in the midst of the spring,
No answering voice in their hearts
to sing;
Only hunger and the winds of pain.
How long since they had felt some
gentle touch;
Had heard some woman's wellloved voice?
How long since love on them had
smiled;
Since they were welcomed by a child
With happy laughter, and all such
Things that mark life from mere
existence?
Vagrants—shadows and shells of
men!
Now brown, now green, as wave on
wave the wheat
Rolled surging in the wind and broke
In little rustlings on the lea,

sea.

There is thus none to relish the true colors of a Great Man. In general, we tend to look at our Great very much as the superstitious peas-

I

I

STRIKE

ants of the Middle Ages used to regard dragons, ogres, and elves. It was
impossible for one of those peasants to conceive that an ogre might have

BRAND

B

bladder trouble, just as much as he had.
Thus I decided to write a series of short plays—returning our Great
Men to the human fold (and when I say "human", I don't necessarily

BRAND

C

BRAND

D

I

mean that always as a compliment).
But to humanize a Hitler demands an apology. For so far has the
current hysteria advanced that I must go at length to argue that there
is really some reason for doing it. In brief, my reason is that the contemplation of remarkable human beings in their array of true colors is
one of the great joys of life. In the midst of all the madness of murders
and glory, all of us can take a little time out and bring down the cutthroats from their horses with an Aristophanic roar. That is the end
of living. That roar of the intellect gives you faith in the riches of life,
whatever your station—and what else can now do a like service? It's
ray of sunshine in an otherwise capitalistic world!
Now to unhorse a tyrant, you need little trite incidents. What would
happen, I ask, if the common situations which are customary in theatrical plots happen to the world's mighty, just as to other matinee idols?
But here's the problem. It is next to impossible to discover such
mortal incidents in the real life of our present dictators. They're all wellhidden. As all our tyrants have risen democratically and unheralded,
there was no biographer to catch them in their obscurity—as was the
case in the absurd, but recorded rise of the third Napoleon. Such mortal
youths are known only to the tyrants themselves, for obviously it's bad
business to expose such facts and thus establish blood kinship to one's
very humblest subject.
Now I don't really know what bits of scarlet color, Hoover, Hitler,
and Stalin have. Therefore, I am inventing bits for them. And that, as
you know, amounts to libel!
But a libel is unethical, you say. And from one point of view, I suppose it is. But let us remember the loftiness of our aim. We are libeling
as the only method of making human our fellow creatures of Earth.
The Greeks—Aristophanes--used it. Why can't we in the good old U. S.
A.? There's plenty of immorality in American business tactics. So,
why can't there be just a little in American letters? To the officials who
have already banned an Elmer Rice portrayal of the Great Men of the
world, I say, gentlemen, let's play the game. Writers will stop picking
on crooked Babbitts, if the latter stop on crooked literati.
I have now almost completed three plays in the technique above discussed. The portraits are as lifelike as the facts permit. Whether I have
been successful remains to be seen. But I am convinced that the libel is
—and rightly so—a brilliant literary tool. What with Walter Winchell
et al, it really should need no introduction in the United States. What it
needs is universal application to the bogies that are now causing so
so much hysteria.
(A libelous Hitler play will appear in a forthcoming issue.)

Milly: But he doesn't love you the
way he does me.
Rachel: Perhaps not in the same
way—although he used to. But we've
gotten beyond that stage. The novelty of our love has worn off, and
we have instead a fine, clear understanding of each other.
Milly: You love him very much,
too, don't you?
Rachel: Yes .. . Yes, I love him so
much that I would gladly get out of
his life . . . if I could only be sure
that you would be good for him.
Milly: And why not? We're both

so crazy about each other—
Rachel: Yes, but will it last?
Milly: I'll always adore him.
Rachel: How can you be sure?
You're awfully young. He flatters
you by his attentions, his boyish eagerness. But if you knew him as I
do, I wonder if you'd feel the same?
Milly: I just can't imagine life
without him.
Rachel: No, of course not—not
now. But by the time you're as old
as I am, you'll probably have changed
your mind a couple of times.
(There is more hurrying in the
halls.)
If you let him get used to your
affection and then snatch it away
suddenly, it would ruin him.
Milly: Oh, why can't we go on the
way we have been? Let him have
both of us— or let's all three be
friends..
Rachel: No, dear, it just wouldn't
work for Gordon. The only thing is
for one of us to walk out of that door
and out of his life. I'll tell you what
we'll do. Go sit down over there and
ask yourself honestly if you are one
who can do the most for him. I'll
sit here and think about it, too, and
if we agree .-. .
